content.content: This problem is way too easy. Not sure about the reasoning to include this in the challenge.\n\nI was so excited, because a mail was sent from Leetcode that on 7th 12 am pst, a brand new problem is released. So I was wide awake, anticipating this one.
The question is very easy, but surely easy problems are not aimed towards people anticipating & waiting for problem releases... probably hards are more your fort\xE9

The question is not well stated. 

> "If there are duplicates in arr, count them separately."

A common understanding of this condition is that, if the input has [1,1,2], then [1,2] is considered as a pair, and another 1 cannot be counted since there is no corresponding 2.

However, the OJ actually counts [1,1,2] as two pairs. So, you should say:

"If there are duplicates in arr, they could be counted repeatedly."
+1, I misunderstood the question just like you described. The problem description should be made more clear.

In case arr = [1,3,2,3,5,0]. 
Step 1 - I've created a list object from the set(arr(x+1). So my list = [1, 2, 3, 4, 6] (Each unique element in the arr + 1)
Step 2 - Check how many number from my list are in the arr. Answer is 4 (1,3,2,3).

Why I got Wrong Answer with expected value=3? Do I misunderstand something?
I am also having the same query for this particular testcase. so, have you got clarity about it.
If you get tripped up by the explanations in the examples, note the misspelling:\ncause -> \'cus
